title.narrative: Live Power Line Maintenance, through The Webster Group

description.narrative: This Reverse Trade Mission ("RTM") is designed to support the planned establishment of Live Wire Maintenance and Repair ("LWMR") in Turkey. The objective of this RTM is to familiarize up to fifteen high-ranking officials from Turkey's energy sector with advanced U.S. technologies, best practices and techniques, as well as regulations for LWMR operations. This would then enable the Turkish delegates to have a better framework to implement a nationwide LWMR strategy in Turkey.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Reverse Trade Mission - Hospital Digitization and Cancer Technologies, through The Webster Group

description.narrative: This Turkey Hospital Digitization and Cancer Technologies RTM will bring senior public health officials from Turkey's Ministry of Health (MoH), public-private partnership hospitals, and private hospitals to the U.S. to familiarize them with U.S. technologies, equipment, and best practices in the medical imaging and radiation therapy technologies sector. The RTM will support the MoH in its strategic efforts to modernize and improve Turkey's healthcare system.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Tupras Refining and Petrochemicals Reverse Trade Mission (RTM), through Gas Technology Institute

description.narrative: This Turkey Tupras Refining and Petrochemicals Reverse Trade Mission (RTM) would bring delegates such as managers, technical specialists and engineers from Tupras and the four refineries it operates to the U.S. to familiarize them with the U.S. technologies, processes and best practices in the refining and petrochemicals sector. The RTM is anticipated to support Tupras as it pursues its refining sector strategic planning process.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Open RAN Pilot Project, through Parallel Wireless, Inc.

description.narrative: USTDA is funding a pilot project to enable Trk Telekom to establish a laboratory test environment for Open RAN solutions and integrate Parallel Wireless technology into its commercial network. The pilot project would create a test environment for 2G, 3G, 4G, and 5G Open RAN solutions from Parallel Wireless and would enable their installation, as well as installation of 5G Open RAN solutions at five field sites on the Trk Telekom network.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Open Radio Access Network Pilot Project Feasibility Study, through Parallel Wireless, Inc.

description.narrative: USTDA is funding a pilot project to enable Trk Telekom to establish a laboratory test environment for open radio access network (RAN) solutions and integrate Parallel Wireless technology into its commercial network. The pilot project would create a test environment for second generation (2G), third generation (3G), fourth generation (4G), and fifth generation (5G) Open RAN solutions from Parallel Wireless and would enable their installation, as well as installation of 5G open RAN solutions at five field sites on the Trk Telekom network.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Ankara Water Digitalization Feasibility Study, through Enterprise - United States Unknown

description.narrative: This grant funds a feasibility study for Ankara Su ve Kanalizasyon Idaresi (ASK), the public water utility of the Ankara Metropolitan Municipality, to upgrade its critical digital infrastructure and water monitoring and management systems. This feasibility study will provide ASK with a detailed technical plan and financial models to modernize its critical digital infrastructure and would allow ASK to reduce water distribution losses and improve the energy efficiency and cybersecurity of its operations, as well as reduce GHG emissions.

title.narrative: Definitional Mission - Electricity Transmission and Distribution, through U.S. Government - Trade and Development Agency

description.narrative: This definitional mission identified and evaluated project opportunities in the electricity transmission and distribution sub-sector in Turkey for USTDA funding consideration. Turkey has experienced consistent growth in electric power demand, which requires additional transmission and distribution capacity and efficiency and holds substantial opportunities for U.S. suppliers of goods, services, and technology in this sub-sector.

title.narrative: Definitional Mission - Information and Communication Technology Sector, through International Consulting & Development Corporation

description.narrative: This definitional mission is identifying and evaluating project opportunities in the information and communications technology (ICT) sector in Turkey for USTDA funding consideration. Turkey has experienced consistent growth in this area due to large government investments, strong consumer demand, and robust private sector spending, and thus this sector holds substantial opportunities for U.S. suppliers of goods, services, and technology in the ICT field.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - 17 MW Seyhan Hydrokinetic Power Project, through Government of Turkey

description.narrative: This $669,875 grant to the Electricity Generating Company of Turkey (EUAS) for a feasibility study (FS) on installation of a 17 megawatt hydrokinetic electric power generation project at the Seyhan hydropower plant installation in Turkey supports renewable energy development and increased generation capacity at the plant. The FS is determining the conceptual design and technical and economic feasibility of the project. This project could lead to installation of additional hydrokinetic power projects in Turkey.

This FS is promoting the efficiency of electricity distribution by expanding the existing supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) systems, as well as by implementing a conceptual design to evaluate the integration of advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) technology into the electrical grid and power storage solutions.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Coal Gasification Project, through Government of Turkey

description.narrative: This $437,020 grant supported a feasibility study examining technical and economic aspects of a proposed pilot plant that would convert coal into substitute natural gas, which would then be introduced into Turkey's gas transmission system. This plant would use existing coal resources to create a new energy source which would have a net lower environmental impact than combustion of the same coal for power production. The grantee was Turkiye Komur Isletmeleri Kurumu, a state-owned mining company in Turkey.

title.narrative: Reverse Trade Mission - Geothermal Energy, through Koeppen, Elliot & Associates, Ltd.

description.narrative: The Geothermal Energy Reverse Trade Mission helped Turkish geothermal energy developers to learn about U.S. technology and solutions and make connections with U.S. vendor companies. The visit included participation by senior representatives of private sector geothermal development companies and included travel to Las Vegas, NV and other U.S. locations with geothermal plant operations to demonstrate U.S. technical solutions and best practices. The visit was scheduled to coincide with the 2013 Geothermal Energy Expo to give the delegates a deeper knowledge of geothermal technology and solutions provided by U.S. vendors.

description.narrative: USTDA funding supported the U.S.-Turkey Geothermal Workshop, which was held in October 2014 in Ankara, Turkey. The primary goal of the workshop was to bolster cooperation between U.S. and Turkish companies for the anticipated doubling of geothermal generation in Turkey over the next ten years.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - SOLAR ENERGY TENDER: TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, through U.S. Government - Department of Energy

description.narrative: This $375,400 grant funds technical assistance with the design of evaluation criteria and methods and licensing and performance standards for a planned utility-scale solar power tender in Turkey. The development of the solar power sector in Turkey will help promote energy diversification in Turkey.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - COAL GASIFICATION PROJECT, through Government of Turkey

description.narrative: This $437,020 grant funds a Feasibility Study examining technical and economic aspects of a proposed pilot plant that would use emerging technologies to convert coal into substitute natural gas, which would then be introduced into Turkey's gas transmission system. This plant would use existing coal resources to create a new energy source which would have a net lower environmental impact than combustion of the same coal for power production. The Grantee is Turkiye Komur Isletmeleri Kurumu, a state-owned mining company in Turkey.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Desk Study - Coal Gasification Project DS, through Energy Markets Group

description.narrative: This $3,000 desk study reviews potential modifications to the TOR and budget for the Coal Gasification Feasibility Study in Turkey (USTDA Activity # 2009-81021A).

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - ENERGY DEMAND AND SUPPLY PROJECTIONS AND ENERGY PLANNING, through U.S. Government - Department of Energy

description.narrative: This $228,686 Technical Assistance (TA) activity, entitled Energy Demand and Supply Projections and Energy Planning, provides assistance to Turkey's Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (MENR). The TA includes a needs assessment and the development of two sets of training courses and workshops to assist MENR officials in applying models developed by the Department of Energy's Argonne National Laboratory to the Turkish electricity market.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - FLOOD FORECASTING AND EARLY WARNING SYSTEM, through Government of Turkey

description.narrative: This $507,420 funds a Flood Forecasting and Early Warning System Feasibliity Study (FS) for the Turkish State Meteorological Service (TSMS). The FS develops an implementation plan to assist TSMS in determining its national-level Flood Forecasting and Early Warning System needs, including hardware, software, Geographic Information Systems (GISs), Relational Database Management Systems (RDMSs), sensors, weather and water monitoring equipment, communications equipment, and modeling systems. The FS will reduce economic losses, and risks to life, health, and safety, due to flooding in Turkey.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - TURKEY: ISTAC WASTE-TO-ENERGY PLANT, through Government of Turkey

description.narrative: This $491,160 feasibility study analyzes a waste-to-energy facility for ISTAC, the municipal waste processing and management company for the Greater Istanbul Municipality in Turkey. The study examines the proposed waste-to-energy facility in Istanbul to help Turkey meet municipal solid waste incineration targets set forth by the European Union, as well as provide a much-needed renewable energy source.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

sector.narrative: Energy generation, renewable sources - multiple technologies

title.narrative: Orientation Visit - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT SECTOR REVERSE TRADE MISSION, through MFM Lamey Group, LLC

description.narrative: This $233,788 Reverse Trade Mission brings representatives of the Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality, the Istanbul Governorship, and the Prime Ministry Disaster and Emergency Management Authority to the United States to meet with U.S. companies active in the emergency management sector and U.S. Government agencies. The Turkish authorities referenced above are developing Emergency Operations Centers and engaging in other emergency management activities, presenting opportunities for U.S. firms in this sector.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Definitional Mission - ELECTRIC POWER SECTOR, through Energy Markets Group

description.narrative: This $35,000 Definitional Mission identifies and evaluates opportunities in the electric power sector in Turkey for USTDA funding consideration. Turkey has begun the process of privatizing its electrical distribution companies, and significant investments will be required by the private distribution companies to modernize the grid.

title.narrative: Middle East Technical University (METU) Smart Campus Project, through Willdan Energy Solutions

description.narrative: USTDA is funding this technical assistance (TA) to support the Middle East Technical University (METU) in developing a smart and sustainable campus. The TA explores the benefits of applying advanced technology solutions to enhance the areas of smart energy, smart transportation, smart water management, smart buildings and Information and Communication Technology ("ICT"), management and control systems. In addition to the development of detailed sector strategies, the TA provides technical, operational and financial guidance to serve as a roadmap for implementing the METU Smart Campus Project.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Middle East Technical University (METU) Smart Campus Project, through Willdan Energy Solutions

description.narrative: METU Smart Campus Project Technical Assistance

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Middle East Technical University (METU) Smart Campus Project, through Willdan Energy Solutions

description.narrative: USTDA is funding this technical assistance (TA) to support the Middle East Technical University (METU) in developing a smart and sustainable campus. The TA explores the benefits of applying advanced technology solutions to enhance the areas of smart energy, smart transportation, smart water management, smart buildings and Information and Communication Technology ("ICT"), management and control systems. In addition to the development of detailed sector strategies, the TA provides technical, operational and financial guidance to serve as a roadmap for implementing the METU Smart Campus Project. Ultimately, the goal of the smart campus project is to enable METU to determine how to best achieve integration of campus infrastructure and services through an integrated, centrally managed and operated project. This Project Memorandum serves to update the Terms of Reference for the Middle East Technical University Smart Campus TA (Activity Number: 2017-21006A).

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - Middle East Technical University (Metu) Smart Campus Project, through Willdan Energy Solutions

description.narrative: USTDA is funding this technical assistance (TA) to support the Middle East Technical University (METU) in developing a smart and sustainable campus. The TA explores the benefits of applying advanced technology solutions to enhance the areas of smart energy, smart transportation, smart water management, smart buildings and Information and Communication Technology ("ICT"), management and control systems. In addition to the development of detailed sector strategies, the TA provides technical, operational and financial guidance to serve as a roadmap for implementing the METU Smart Campus Project. Ultimately, the goal of the smart campus project is to enable METU to determine how to best achieve integration of campus infrastructure and services through an integrated, centrally managed and operated project. This Project Memorandum serves to update the Terms of Reference for the Middle East Technical University Smart Campus TA.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Air Simulation for the New Istanbul Airport, through Jeppesen Sanderson, Inc.

description.narrative: USTDA's contribution of will partially fund a technical assistance to design the optimal airspace, runway approaches and air traffic control operating procedures for the New Istanbul Airport. The New Istanbul Airport is scheduled to open in 2018 and when completed in 2024, it will be one of the largest in the world, hosting 150 million passengers annually on flights to more than 350 destinations. Accordingly, GA Havaliman Iletmesi A.. (IGA), the concessionaire that will operate the airport for 25-years, is seeking technical assistance to ensure that the airspace operates at sufficient capacity to meet the anticipated traffic demand on the opening day in 2018. This Project Memorandum serves to update the Grant Agreement for the Terms of Reference for the Air Simulation for the New Istanbul Airport Technical Assistance (USTDA Activity No. 2016-21007A). Funding in the amount of $370.400 is being added to the Turkey Air Simulation for the New Istanbul Airport Technical Assistance.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles
